title: Thermostat, "Nest Learning Thermostat", 2011
provenance: 2012: acquired directly from manufacturer, Nest Labs
description: Large circular face, black when power is off, surrounded by circular, matte stainless steel housing with control ring around face.
justification: The Nest Learning Thermostat has been called the “iPod of thermostats”—perhaps because its creators, alumni of Apple, were leaders in creating the iPod and early iPhones. The thermostat may do for home energy what the iPod did for portable music-playing: revolutionize it. The thermostat, Nest Labs’s first product, officially went on sale in November 2011. The company began taking preorders in late October, 2011 and sold out within 72 hours. According to the social media news and blog website, Mashable, 90% of programmable thermostats are “rarely or never programmed,” and the sleek design and automatic features of Nest’s device could improve those numbers. The temperature is depicted in bold numbers, front and center, on the large circular face within a simple circular matt stainless steel housing. Functionality is based around a ring, similar to that of the iPod. Moving your finger around the outer ring changes the temperature—the thermostat face turns blue when it is cooling, and red when heating; pressing the ring provides access to all of the thermostat’s settings. Users must initially program the thermostat themselves in the morning, evening, or when they are out of the house, but it eventually remembers their patterns and reverts to self-programming. The device can also detect if anyone is in the room, and adjust the temperature accordingly.  Additional features include the ability to control home temperature on the go—from a laptop, smartphone, or tablet—automatic software updates, security features, and a green leaf icon that appears when the device is set to an energy-saving level.  The Nest thermostat uses technology from across a range of industries: sensors from the medical industry, electronics from smartphones, software from the open-source community, and learning technology. Thermostats control half of a home’s energy uses, and are responsible for 10% of U.S. energy consumption. There are a quarter-billion thermostats in the U.S. and another ten million are purchased each year. However, according to Nest co-founder Matt Rogers, the “eyesore” cream-colored-plastic-box thermostat had not changed much in the past twenty years. Rogers, with co-founder Tony Fadell, aimed to turn the thermostat into a better-functioning and better-looking object that people would actually want to interact with, and that would lower energy usage and heating/cooling bills. Nest Labs is revolutionizing what seems to be a forgotten industry, in part to reduce energy consumption and benefit the environment. The company is also part of a new wave of designers.
